page.title: 06Local History,Wick
page.content:
The town of Wick,made a Royal Burgh in 1589, is divided into two parts by the river-Wick and Pulteney.Wick was called Vik ,meaning bay ,by the Vikings.Pulteney was called after Sir William Pulteney who was chairman of the Fishery commission in 1808.
Many farms and villages have names ending in -ster which means homestead or small homes.
Along the bank of Wick river there are two statues.One was erected in memory of James T Calder,who wrote the History of Caithness,which is well read by people today.The other was to the memory of John Alexander,M.D.who was the medical officer in the county in the late 19th century.
